NAACL-2021 takeaways

Written By: Anna Liednikova

After visiting conference NAACL-2021, I would like to share the works that I found intereting in NLP

"I'm Not Mad": Commonsense Implications of Negation and Contradiction

Paper || Poster || Video

Negation is one of the most common problems in the NLP tasks. Liwei Jiang, Antoine Bosselut, Chandra Bhagavatula and Yejin Choi presented a new step forward - ANION, a new com-monsense knowledge graph with 624K if-then rules focusing on negated and contradictory events. They compare the result of this model with ATOMIC. Both knowledge-graph created manually by populating social commonsense knowledge about event pre-conditions, event post-conditions, and static attributes in the form of natural languageif-then rules. Drawback of ATOMIC that it doesn’t contains a lot of negatives samples (only 2.1%). The table below shows the main rules used by the authors.

I am curious to see how using this knowledge graph can help improve performance of NLI models and if it could be used for improving datasets quality by reducing contradiction inside them.

TuringAdvice: A Generative and Dynamic Evaluation of Language Use

Paper || Poster || Video

Another promising dataset is TuringAdvice created and relased by Rowan Zellers, Yejin Choi, Elizabeth Clark, Ali Farhadi, Ari Holtzman, Lianhui Qin. TuringAdvice is a challenge for AI systems, to test their understanding of natural language. The key idea is that must generate advice in response to someone who is seeking it. To pass the challenge, the machine’s advice must be at least as helpful as human-written advice for that situation.

I believe that giving a proper advice could be the next important compontent of the dialogue systems as well as empathy. Looking forward to the follo-up work!

mT5: A Massively Multilingual Pre-trained Text-to-Text Transformer

Paper || Poster

In this paper, a Google team introduced mT5, a multilingual variant of T5 that was pre-trained on a new Common Crawl-based dataset covering 101 languages. There are 5 sizes availble: small, Base, Large, XL, XXL. You can find them all at official repository or test right away on Hugging Face platform

As a reminder: T5 is Text-to-Text generation model, that was tranied on plently of NLP tasks at once, so that you can use the same ‘black-box’ with a short idenifier of the task in the beginning of input to control the format of the output.

{ConVEx}: Data-Efficient and Few-Shot Slot Labeling

Paper || Poster

Matthew Henderson and Ivan Vulić presented ConVEx (Conversational Value Extractor), an efficient pretraining and fine-tuning neural approach for slot-labeling dialog tasks. I was glad to see this work, since it seems to me to be one of follow-up works of ConveRT embeddings, which are very fast and precise for dialogue response retrieval.

On learning and representing social meaning in NLP: a sociolinguistic perspective

Paper || Poster

Dong Nguyen presenting this position paper in collaboration with Jack Grieve and Laura Rosseel. This work immediately caught my attention since I saw previous work on COLING 2020.

They way we speak can tell a lot about us and our relation with our interlocor, it’s changes over time and with different generations and events. It could be very interesting to use this information not only for analysis, but also for controlable utterance generation.

The Importance of Modeling Social Factors of Language: Theory and Practice

Paper || Poster

Dirk Hovy and Diyi Yang

Human-like informative conversations: Better acknowledgements using conditional mutual information

Paper || Poster

Ashwin Paranjape, Christopher Manning

Beyond Black & White: Leveraging Annotator Disagreement via Soft-Label Multi-Task Learning

Paper || Poster

Tommaso Fornaciari presented his joing work with Dirk Hovy, Silviu Paun, Barbara Plank, Massimo Poesio, Alexandra Uma about the importance of stepping back from “black and white” labels, but instead of that to look at their distribution.

Explainable Multi-hop Verbal Reasoning Through Internal Monologue

Paper || Poster

Zhengzhong Liang, Steven Bethard, Mihai Surdeanu

Negative language transfer in learner English: A new dataset

Paper || Poster

Another interesting work is detecting language transfer in English presented by Leticia Farias Wanderley, Carrie Demmans Epp, Nicole (Zixin) Zhao.

That’s true that learning a new language, we tend to transfer our knowledge from other languages to a new one. On the one hand it could help to detect your original language, on the other hand revealing such patterns could help the learners to develop faster and in more effient way. Automatic personalized corrective feedback can help language learners from different backgrounds better acquire a new language.

Open-Domain Question Answering Goes Conversational via Question Rewriting

Poster

Raviteja Anantha, Svitlana Vakulenko, Srinivas Chappidi, Shayne Longpre, Stephen Pulman, Zhucheng Tu

Shared task on SCAI QReCC: https://scai.info/scai-qrecc/

Is Incoherence Surprising? Targeted Evaluation of Coherence Prediction from Language Models

Paper || Poster

Anne Beyer has presented her work with Sharid Loáiciga, David Schlangen about capacity of the models

It remind me about FED framework for dialogue evaluation. The work seems to be very interesting and enough useful for few-turns dialogues, but doesn’t giving the expected feedback for long dialogues since they are already pretty unique, so the perplexety is pretty low.

Preregistering NLP research

Paper || Poster

Emiel van Miltenburg, Emiel Krahmer, Chris van der Lee
